Corpus examples –
[...] ’Se glé bheag de chobhair a thug a’ Phàrlamaid a riamh do ’n Ghàidhlig no do fhoghlum agus do litreachas na Gàidhlig. Cuin a chualas ball-Pàrlamaid a’ togail a ghuth a dh’ iarraidh leasachaidh do staid Gàidhlig ann an Albainn?
The Parliament has given very little assistance ever to the Gaelic language or to Gaelic education and literature. When has a member of Parliament been heard raising his voice to demand improvement for the state of Gaelic in Scotland? td. 9, ‘Air an Spiris’
[...] ’Se glé bheag de chobhair a thug a’ Phàrlamaid a riamh do ’n Ghàidhlig no do fhoghlum agus do litreachas na Gàidhlig. Cuin a chualas ball-Pàrlarnaid a’ togail a ghuth a dh’ iarraidh leasachaidh do staid Gàidhlig ann an Albainn? Am bi cothrom a nis aig cuideigin a ghuth a thogail, anns an t-suidheachadh iongantach a th’ againn anns a’ Phàrlamaid ùr? Chan eil sinn ag iarraidh air an duine so, ma tha e ann, a’ Ghàidhlig a chur air thoiseach air lòn is obair is caitheamh-beatha an t-sluaigh. Chan eil sinn ag iarraidh ach beagan ceartais.
[...] The Parliament has given very little assistance ever to the Gaelic language or to Gaelic education and literature. When has a member of Parliament been heard raising his voice to demand improvement for the state of Gaelic in Scotland? Will someone have an opportunity now to raise his voice, in the unexpected situation we have in the new Parliament? We are not asking of this person, if he exists, to prioritise Gaelic over food and jobs and the populations standard of living. We only want a modicum of justice. td. 9, ‘Air an Spiris’
[...] ’Se glé bheag de chobhair a thug a’ Phàrlamaid a riamh do ’n Ghàidhlig no do fhoghlum agus do litreachas na Gàidhlig. [...] Dé na rudan a dh’ fhaodadh sinn iarraidh? Tuilleadh de luchd-teagaisg ’s de luchd-ceasnachaidh Gàidhlig. Airgead gu leabhraichean uallachadh is a chlo-bhualadh. Barrachd tìde air an réidio agus air telebhisean. [...] Chan eil an sin ach rud no dhà a dh’ fhaodamaid iarraidh. Tha Comunn nan Croitearan air nì de ’n t-seòrsa so iarraidh mar tha, air a’ Bh.B.C. [...]
[...] The Parliament has given very little assistance ever to the Gaelic language or to Gaelic education and literature. [...] What are the things that we could demand? More Gaelic teachers and inspectors. Money to prepare and print books. More time on the radio and on television. [...] Those are just a couple of things that we could demand. The Crofters’ Society has demanded something of this kind already, on the BBC. [...] td. 9, ‘Air an Spiris’

[...] The Parliament has given very little assistance ever to the Gaelic language or to Gaelic education and literature. When has a member of Parliament been heard raising his voice to demand improvement for the state of Gaelic in Scotland? Will someone have an opportunity now to raise his voice, in the unexpected situation we have in the new Parliament? Tha An Comunn Gaidhealach a’ bruidhinn air Seanaileir ùr a thaghadh a bhios os cionn obair a’ Chomuinn. [...] Bhiodh a leòr aige ri dhèanamh an toiseach ag ath-nuadhachadh dreach a’ Chomuinn. [...] Ach dh’ fheumadh am Fear-stiùiridh ùr barrachd air a sin a dhèanamh. Dh’ fheumadh e siubhal a dhèanamh eadar Rubha Robhanais agus Ceann Bharraidh, eadar am Parbh is Maol Chinn-tìre, agus cha deanadh math dha dìochuimhneachadh gu robh obair a’ Chomuinn a’ buntainn ri Coimisean nan Croitearan an Inbhirnis, ri Roinn an Fhoghluim an Dùn-Eideann, agus ri Tigh nan Cumantan an Lunnainn. An duine a theid do gach àite dhiubh sin, agus a bheir barrachd air còmhradh leis dhachaidh, nì e feum do ’n Chomunn is do ’n Ghàidhlig. Tha sinn a’ guidhe ’s ag iarraidh gu lorg An Comunn duine de ’n t-seòrsa so.
The Highland Society is talking about choosing a new General who will oversee the Society’s work. [...] He would have enough to do initially reforming the Society. [...] But the new leader would have to do more than (just) that. He would have to travel between the Butt of Lewis and Barra Head, between Cape Wrath and the Mull of Kintyre, and he should not forget that the Society’s work is related to the Crofters’ Commission in Inverness, to the Education Department in Edinburgh, and to the House of Commons in London. The person who goes to each of those places, and who brings home more than (just) conversation, will benefit the Society and the Gaelic language. We are praying and asking that The Society will find a person of this kind. td. 105, ‘Air an Spiris’
